Editor's Note: This petition was
submitted to the NEWS-LETTER by
the Interfraternity Board.

In complete defiance to every other
fraternity on the campus, Phi Gamma_ Delta gave a formal dance for
freshmen at a downtown club, Wednesday night.
This action is a direct violation of
the Interfraternity Rushing Agreement which specifically states "There
will be no restriction placed on the
entertainment provided by the fraternities for the freshmen on their
alloted date, except that the entertainment must be confined tco the
Hopkins chapter house." While there
is no signed agreement between the
fraternities, it is considered a gentleman's pact, in keeping with the
spirit of the Honor System.
Feeling High
Student feeling against the Phi
Gams has been running high. The
general concensus of opinion seems
to be that the Phi Gams have violated the Honor System and "have not
acted in a manner befitting Hopkins
gentlemen."
To signify their censure and condemnation of the Phi
Gamma Delta fraternity, the members of the Interfraternity Board circulated a petition which was signed
by 10 of the 12 members on the
Board. The petition states in part,
"that the action of the condemned
chapter is 'unbecoming a gentleman'
and `prejudicial to the honor of the
University.'"

Excellent Showing Against
Washington Squad Lends
Confidence, Experience
By RED GLANTZ
Co North, young man, go North!
That's what the Johns Hopkins pigskin carriers are doing. They're due
to play Swarthmore College at
Swarthmore, Penna., tomorrow afternoon. It's the seasonal clash, and big
things will be done and seen.
The Jay footballers, after an excellent showing against Washington
College, promise to display an even
greater amount of precision and
fight. Coach George Darley has been
busy ironing out the defects found
in the opening match, and has kept
the future Tarzans at tackling and
blocking practice for the past week.
At the field, all is hustle and bustle.
Does Coach Darley have a trick card
1-1P his sleeve? Will he try out his
new spinner reverse play against the
Garnets?
The gridmen have been going
around with grim faces and a fighting look in their eyes. They're out for
blood this time, no doubt about that.
At any rate, when the whistle goes
off for the kick-off and the two
teams meet for that first bodily contact, Swarthmore will know that the
Jays are in the game.
Garnets Drop First Two
Swarthmore has a large number
of experienced men and a promising
crop of new material. Of these, Coach
George Pfann has molded a team
Which, though losing its first two
games, has displayed a good brand
Of ball even in defeat.
The initial game of the year with
Washington College was lost 13-6,
but it was a moral victory for the
arnets, having held a much heavier and more experienced squad to
two touchdowns while scoring once
themselves.
Camill "Bud" Peter
was the outstanding star for the
Pennsylvanians, breaking loose several times for substantial gains and
Showing himself to be a veritable
tartar on defense.

G

Upset By Dickinson
Swarthmore's second defeat was
something in the nature of an upset
When they lost to Dickinson, 14-7.
The Pfannmen scored their only
Marker when Ben Cooper circled end
for 72 yards and crossed the Dickinson goal line standing up after having received some nice blocking from
his mates. For most of the contest,
however, the Garnet gridmen were
on the defense, trying to stop the
off-tackle slants of Shore, Clark,
Kiehl, and other Dickinson stalwarts.
Several disastrous fumbles halted
any threats that Swarthmore made
t?wards carrying on a sustained
drive. The game was costly in that
Dudley Perkins, star halfback and
one of the most effective passers and
Punters on the squad was disabled.
He suffered a recurrence of an old
knee injury, and it is doubtful that
lie will see any action this year.
The Dickinson game showed a
Considerable let-down in the quality
Of the ball displayed by the Pfann.inen. The tackling was ragged, the
interference ineffective, and the general morale of the team lower than
that exhibited against Washington.
Teams Evenly Matched

interfrat football league was functioning better than the intramural
league, and I pointed out that the
reason was that the fraternities had
a basis for morale in that they are
each an entity in which the players
stick together in all activities. With
the exception of the New Jersey AllStars and, possibly one or two other
intramural teams, the organizations
are not well-knit.
It seems strange that there can be
found no ties of occupational loyalty
upon which to build intramural athletic competition when every AntiWar Strike reveals so plainly the
breach between the engineers and the
A.B. men. It might not be a bad idea
to have an engineer's league, the
teams to fight for the honor of meeting the winner of an A.B. league and
business league combined. In that
way some sort of continuity might
be inserted into the system. Plaques
might be offered to the winner of
each league and a trophy to the college with the highest total of points
in intercollege competition within the University, all awards to be
displayed in the office of the dean
of the winning college—arts or business or engineers. A college would
have to win three legs on the trophy
to get permanent possession of it. In
such a fashion tradition may be
started and the intramural league be
built up as intercollege leagues.
0—0

Criticism Of
The Plan
Perhaps the chief objection to the
plan I outlined above lies on ethical
grounds. It may be argued that there
is already entirely too big a rupture
in the relations of. the engineers and
the art.'s men. Since they take different courses in different sections of
the campus for the most part, and
since they even segregate in the matter of fraternities, the two sets of
men have little to do with, one another. I think that the problem oT
making these two units realize that
they are each a part of a single institution that stands out in the academic world—in any world, for that
matter—as the epitome of the scientific attitude of open-mindedness and
of thorough investigation of facts, T.
think that this problem is not beneath the consideration of the highest administrators at the Hopkins
Following that line, it may be
pointed out that I would act upon
the distinctions that already exist,
and would construct an even larger
barrier between the two groups. I
can't agree with that. As I see it,
the source of the trouble is the lack
of contact between the engineers and
the arts men. Playing football
against one another would certainly
bring them into close contact—in
more than one way. When men meet
men they didn't know well before in
some game like football, they usually
get a new respect for them. I believe that this has been the case with
the fraternities. Speaking as a fraternity man I can say that we have
yet to meet a team whose men we
didn't think more of after playing
them for the courage and sportsmanship they showed.

To Renew Cross-Country
Feud; Close Race Seen
The Hopkins cross-country team
will inaugurate its season tomorrow when it travels to Bethlehem,
Pa., to engage the Lehigh harriers.
The run will mark the first competition between the squads in the sport
since 1931.
According to past results, a hardfought battle should be waged. The
Jays captured the last encounter by
the score of 27-28, when a Hopkins
runner, Tom Neely, came up into
eighth place in the last half-mile to
capture the deciding point.
Probable Starters Picked
Coach Hambleton has not definitely
picked the starting squad, but six of
the seven participants are rather
certain of their places. Captain Emmert, Sholtes, Lyman, Bob and
George Brown, and Moxley are the
leaders, while Castelle and Schultz
are engaged in a close struggle tor
the other open position.
Injuries have taken their toll during the past week, with both Lyman
and Moxley suffering from turned
ankles. However, they have been
training for several days, and should
be in good shape tomorrow. Lack of
practice has also hurt the squad,
since a great majority are engineers
and cannot allow much time from
their studies.
Interscholastics To Be Held Here
Hambleton, in addition to coaching
the cross-country team, has been
spending some time in plans for the
coming annual interscholastic championships held at Homewood and
sponsored by the University chapter
of Spiked Shoe, national honorary
track fraternity.
By all indications, the meet Will
attract a greater entry list than at
any time in the past. Letters have
been received from Syracuse Central,
national individual
boasting the
championship. Knott Terrace, the
winner of the team trophy, and Patterson Central is another powerful aggregation. The contest will take place
on November 23 at 12 noon, and entry blanks are already obtainable
from Irving Leberfeld.

Harrier Managers Wanted
All freshmen interested in a crosscountry managerial berth are urged
to report to Coach Waldo Hambleton,
Manager Roy Hartman or Milton
Saul today at 4:30 p. m. The position
has not been filled' as yet, and all
candidates will be, carefully considered.

This year will see another epoch
of intramural play. However, the first
few games of touch football have
shown the spirit of the fraternities
to be even better than that of last
year. Perhaps the reason might be
that the frat men did not see what
they were getting for victory. Now
that they've all been gazing rather
enviously at the newly-awarded
plaque, they are all the more determined to take part in interfraternity
athletic activity.
At any rate, intramural competition, as a means of giving every man
in school a chance to play ball, is an
excellent idea. The Physical Education Department, headed by Dr.
Schaffer, ought to be given a word
of praise for the fine work they've
done.

Editor's Note: This petition was
submitted to the NEWS-LETTER by
the Interfraternity Board.

In complete defiance to every other
fraternity on the campus, Phi Gamma_ Delta gave a formal dance for
freshmen at a downtown club, Wednesday night.
This action is a direct violation of
the Interfraternity Rushing Agreement which specifically states "There
will be no restriction placed on the
entertainment provided by the fraternities for the freshmen on their
alloted date, except that the entertainment must be confined tco the
Hopkins chapter house." While there
is no signed agreement between the
fraternities, it is considered a gentleman's pact, in keeping with the
spirit of the Honor System.
Feeling High
Student feeling against the Phi
Gams has been running high. The
general concensus of opinion seems
to be that the Phi Gams have violated the Honor System and "have not
acted in a manner befitting Hopkins
gentlemen."
To signify their censure and condemnation of the Phi
Gamma Delta fraternity, the members of the Interfraternity Board circulated a petition which was signed
by 10 of the 12 members on the
Board. The petition states in part,
"that the action of the condemned
chapter is 'unbecoming a gentleman'
and `prejudicial to the honor of the
University.'"

Excellent Showing Against
Washington Squad Lends
Confidence, Experience
By RED GLANTZ
Co North, young man, go North!
That's what the Johns Hopkins pigskin carriers are doing. They're due
to play Swarthmore College at
Swarthmore, Penna., tomorrow afternoon. It's the seasonal clash, and big
things will be done and seen.
The Jay footballers, after an excellent showing against Washington
College, promise to display an even
greater amount of precision and
fight. Coach George Darley has been
busy ironing out the defects found
in the opening match, and has kept
the future Tarzans at tackling and
blocking practice for the past week.
At the field, all is hustle and bustle.
Does Coach Darley have a trick card
1-1P his sleeve? Will he try out his
new spinner reverse play against the
Garnets?
The gridmen have been going
around with grim faces and a fighting look in their eyes. They're out for
blood this time, no doubt about that.
At any rate, when the whistle goes
off for the kick-off and the two
teams meet for that first bodily contact, Swarthmore will know that the
Jays are in the game.
Garnets Drop First Two
Swarthmore has a large number
of experienced men and a promising
crop of new material. Of these, Coach
George Pfann has molded a team
Which, though losing its first two
games, has displayed a good brand
Of ball even in defeat.
The initial game of the year with
Washington College was lost 13-6,
but it was a moral victory for the
arnets, having held a much heavier and more experienced squad to
two touchdowns while scoring once
themselves.
Camill "Bud" Peter
was the outstanding star for the
Pennsylvanians, breaking loose several times for substantial gains and
Showing himself to be a veritable
tartar on defense.

G

Upset By Dickinson
Swarthmore's second defeat was
something in the nature of an upset
When they lost to Dickinson, 14-7.
The Pfannmen scored their only
Marker when Ben Cooper circled end
for 72 yards and crossed the Dickinson goal line standing up after having received some nice blocking from
his mates. For most of the contest,
however, the Garnet gridmen were
on the defense, trying to stop the
off-tackle slants of Shore, Clark,
Kiehl, and other Dickinson stalwarts.
Several disastrous fumbles halted
any threats that Swarthmore made
t?wards carrying on a sustained
drive. The game was costly in that
Dudley Perkins, star halfback and
one of the most effective passers and
Punters on the squad was disabled.
He suffered a recurrence of an old
knee injury, and it is doubtful that
lie will see any action this year.
The Dickinson game showed a
Considerable let-down in the quality
Of the ball displayed by the Pfann.inen. The tackling was ragged, the
interference ineffective, and the general morale of the team lower than
that exhibited against Washington.
Teams Evenly Matched

interfrat football league was functioning better than the intramural
league, and I pointed out that the
reason was that the fraternities had
a basis for morale in that they are
each an entity in which the players
stick together in all activities. With
the exception of the New Jersey AllStars and, possibly one or two other
intramural teams, the organizations
are not well-knit.
It seems strange that there can be
found no ties of occupational loyalty
upon which to build intramural athletic competition when every AntiWar Strike reveals so plainly the
breach between the engineers and the
A.B. men. It might not be a bad idea
to have an engineer's league, the
teams to fight for the honor of meeting the winner of an A.B. league and
business league combined. In that
way some sort of continuity might
be inserted into the system. Plaques
might be offered to the winner of
each league and a trophy to the college with the highest total of points
in intercollege competition within the University, all awards to be
displayed in the office of the dean
of the winning college—arts or business or engineers. A college would
have to win three legs on the trophy
to get permanent possession of it. In
such a fashion tradition may be
started and the intramural league be
built up as intercollege leagues.
0—0

Criticism Of
The Plan
Perhaps the chief objection to the
plan I outlined above lies on ethical
grounds. It may be argued that there
is already entirely too big a rupture
in the relations of. the engineers and
the art.'s men. Since they take different courses in different sections of
the campus for the most part, and
since they even segregate in the matter of fraternities, the two sets of
men have little to do with, one another. I think that the problem oT
making these two units realize that
they are each a part of a single institution that stands out in the academic world—in any world, for that
matter—as the epitome of the scientific attitude of open-mindedness and
of thorough investigation of facts, T.
think that this problem is not beneath the consideration of the highest administrators at the Hopkins
Following that line, it may be
pointed out that I would act upon
the distinctions that already exist,
and would construct an even larger
barrier between the two groups. I
can't agree with that. As I see it,
the source of the trouble is the lack
of contact between the engineers and
the arts men. Playing football
against one another would certainly
bring them into close contact—in
more than one way. When men meet
men they didn't know well before in
some game like football, they usually
get a new respect for them. I believe that this has been the case with
the fraternities. Speaking as a fraternity man I can say that we have
yet to meet a team whose men we
didn't think more of after playing
them for the courage and sportsmanship they showed.

To Renew Cross-Country
Feud; Close Race Seen
The Hopkins cross-country team
will inaugurate its season tomorrow when it travels to Bethlehem,
Pa., to engage the Lehigh harriers.
The run will mark the first competition between the squads in the sport
since 1931.
According to past results, a hardfought battle should be waged. The
Jays captured the last encounter by
the score of 27-28, when a Hopkins
runner, Tom Neely, came up into
eighth place in the last half-mile to
capture the deciding point.
Probable Starters Picked
Coach Hambleton has not definitely
picked the starting squad, but six of
the seven participants are rather
certain of their places. Captain Emmert, Sholtes, Lyman, Bob and
George Brown, and Moxley are the
leaders, while Castelle and Schultz
are engaged in a close struggle tor
the other open position.
Injuries have taken their toll during the past week, with both Lyman
and Moxley suffering from turned
ankles. However, they have been
training for several days, and should
be in good shape tomorrow. Lack of
practice has also hurt the squad,
since a great majority are engineers
and cannot allow much time from
their studies.
Interscholastics To Be Held Here
Hambleton, in addition to coaching
the cross-country team, has been
spending some time in plans for the
coming annual interscholastic championships held at Homewood and
sponsored by the University chapter
of Spiked Shoe, national honorary
track fraternity.
By all indications, the meet Will
attract a greater entry list than at
any time in the past. Letters have
been received from Syracuse Central,
national individual
boasting the
championship. Knott Terrace, the
winner of the team trophy, and Patterson Central is another powerful aggregation. The contest will take place
on November 23 at 12 noon, and entry blanks are already obtainable
from Irving Leberfeld.

Harrier Managers Wanted
All freshmen interested in a crosscountry managerial berth are urged
to report to Coach Waldo Hambleton,
Manager Roy Hartman or Milton
Saul today at 4:30 p. m. The position
has not been filled' as yet, and all
candidates will be, carefully considered.

This year will see another epoch
of intramural play. However, the first
few games of touch football have
shown the spirit of the fraternities
to be even better than that of last
year. Perhaps the reason might be
that the frat men did not see what
they were getting for victory. Now
that they've all been gazing rather
enviously at the newly-awarded
plaque, they are all the more determined to take part in interfraternity
athletic activity.
At any rate, intramural competition, as a means of giving every man
in school a chance to play ball, is an
excellent idea. The Physical Education Department, headed by Dr.
Schaffer, ought to be given a word
of praise for the fine work they've
done.

Fencers Practicing
The fencing squad has already
started informal practice for the
coming season. Many men answered
the first call, and prospects for the
coming season are very encouraging.
Despite the large turnout, men with
any inclination towards the sport
will be welcomed. Practice is being
held every Saturday afternoon at 1
o'clock at the Barn.
